title: Budget will be announced one week after Brexit
text:
Chancellor Sajid Javid hopes to deliver a budget early next month (Picture: AP)

The Government plans to announce its first post-Brexit Budget just days after it hopes Britain will leave the EU.

Chancellor Sajid Javid announced today that he will lay out financial plans for the country on Wednesday, 6 November – but admitted the announcement could be delayed if Boris Johnson’s Brexit plan is rejected by MPs.

Taking place within a week of Britain’s expected departure from the EU on 31 October, Mr Javid has said his first Budget as chancellor will herald the start of an ‘infrastructure revolution’.

But if the UK leaves without a deal, the treasury admits the Budget would be put on hold until ‘the weeks thereafter’.

In those circumstances, the government claims it would ‘act quickly to outline our approach and take early action to support the economy, businesses and households’.

It did not clarify what might happen if it were forced to ask for an extension under the Benn Act, which requires a Brexit delay should a deal with the EU not be agreed by 19 October.

If Brussels does agree to an extension until January, it is understood the Budget will be announced on 6 November as planned.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson with Chancellor Sajid Javid (Picture: AFP)

The Budget Box could make a return on November 6 – or be delayed for a few weeks (Picture: AFP)

The Government insisted this morning that it is ‘committed to securing a deal and leaving on 31 October’.

Mr Javid explained: ‘This will be the first Budget after leaving the EU. I will be setting out our plan to shape the economy for the future and triggering the start of our infrastructure revolution.

‘This is the right and responsible thing to do – we must get on with governing.’

But the Government may not have enough support in Parliament to pass any such Budget, since it does not have a majority. The event is likely to come ahead of a general election, which is widely expected this winter.

What time is the Queen's speech today and who writes it?

The Shadow Chancellor, Labour’s John McDonnell, tweeted: ‘Tories announced budget in November. More of an electioneering stunt than a budget to rebuild our stalling economy and reset the direction of our country’.

A Queen’s Speech is being held today, ahead of a crunch summit of EU leaders later in the week, when the Government hopes a Brexit deal can be thrashed out.

description: Chancellor Sajid Javid says pre-election budget will take place on Wednesday, November 6, days after Brexit takes place.
